body: Interesting analysis! Yes `containsExactly` can and should be improved
Can I take this issue? Disregard previous edit.
@nith2001 and I would like to work on this together.
one comment about the issue is that we want to keep the error message as it is.

@joel-costigliola I looked through the `IterableDiff` class and I have question regarding the statement that "they [Iterables] have to be present in the exact order" from @sarajuhosova.

I thought the order in which an Iterable iterates through its Collection does not always have a fixed order, right? For example, HashSets. As a result, to check for unexpected elements or additional elements, isn't it necessary to iterate through the whole `expected` iterable to look for an element in `actual`?

Numerous edits later ðŸ˜ª... (btw, a little new to dealing heavily with Iterables, so I could definitely be wrong) Hmm, now I'm a tad confused...After doing some digging, it seems as though it may be necessary to iterate through the whole Iterable if it involves something like a HashSet, especially with unequal sizes. If we followed code similar to the suggestion related to IterableDiff, I believe our error handling would become incorrect for Iterables like HashSets, because we would consider certain values as "unexpected actual values" when in reality they should be expected, like the values 13, 14, and 15 in the example above. So the exact order argument might not hold here. Plus, it seems that that IterableDiff_Test lacks testing with iterables that aren't ArrayLists where the ordering could be different, like HashSets.

I guess here the question also is what the difference for unordered datastructures (such as sets) should be between `containsExactly` and `containsExactlyInAnyOrder`. I would argue that to keep the meaning of these the same across all data structures, unordered items should only have the second one ðŸ¤” An iterator, though, is ordered (I guess?), and if you are verifying that instead of the map it comes from, there is still the distinction between these two methods.

Hmm, I second your thoughts on this! But it seems as though our test suite is using exclusively ArrayLists to test both `containsExactly` and `containsExactlyInAnyOrder`. Making the distinction is pretty important as you said, so that may be something that @joel-costigliola will have give some input on, since it seems to be more of a design decision that is out of my hands :-D

On your statement about iterators, it was my understanding that iterators generally follow an order that is based on the implementation, but whether that order is known by the client or not depends on the nature of the data structure. For example, ArrayLists are purposefully designed to have ordering that is clear to the user at all times, while HashSets do not preserve an order that is consistently known by the user in order to prioritize speed. 

I'll have to hold off make any edits until that gets sorted I guess.

`containsExactly` is not a good fit for some `Set` like `HashSets` (but it's fine for `SortedSets` or `LinkedHashSet`), on this one we expect users to know the semantics of the iterables being tested. If the iteration order is not consistent then the assertion will likely fail and that is fine since the iterable did not honor the assertion contract.

`containsExactlyInAnyOrder` can be used with `HashSet` aspointed out by @sarajuhosova. 

> Plus, it seems that that IterableDiff_Test lacks testing with iterables that aren't ArrayLists where the ordering could be different, like HashSets.

I agree that we could have used different iterable types but only those with consistent iteration order (so no `HashSet`).

In my experience we should not rely on `HashSet` iteration even though it could look consistent, I remember on one project tests that relied on this and failed once we migrated to a newer version of java that changes the underlying `HashSet` iteration order.

So moving forward, we should continue treating iterable as if they had a consistent iteration order for `containsExactly` and let users the responsibility to choose the correct assertion for `HashSet`, what we can do though is to enhance the javadoc with a warning to prefer `containsExactlyInAnyOrder` over `containsExactly` for `HashSet` or any iterable whose iteration order is not predictable.

Good discussion btw!

So then to be clear, given the following two iterables:
`actual = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]`
`expected = [9, 9, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4]`

What would be the resulting unexpected actual list and missing actual list with these new changes?
My guess was:
`unexpected actual list = [5]`
`missing actual list = [9, 9]`

But I'm not so sure anymore since my head's kinda boggled right now.
that assertion would fail at the first element (that's the main reason), then to be helpful we do a diff of the iterables with the result you have suggested @nith2001.

Hmmm, so if I tried implementing the IterableDiff to follow this solution, it would require looking ahead of expected iterable copy and remove values from it in future indices, which seems to be the problem causing slower runtime. As a result, if we needed to improve from O(n^2) to O(n) on the error handling, then there might need to be some compromise on how accurate the error message handling will be. 

I'll keep try to hack away at an O(n) solution though!

I don't think it is important that the error handling be O(n), I don't even think it is possible.
Rationale being that tests should succeed most of the time, if they fail it's ok to take a bit more time to provide a good error message.
But...wasn't the reason why the code was running at O(n^2) solely because of the IterableDiff class? And isn't the IterableDiff class crucial to the error handling message?

The analysis that was run was run on succeeding tests and in those it's possible to run in O(n). I'm assuming the idea here is to first try to check the correctness in O(n) and if there is a failure, only then resort to the O(n^2) algorithm to report the errors. That way, in passing cases, the check is still only O(n).
